docs.snippet: Fox Searchlight made the decision to bring the kids of "Slumdog Millionaire" to Hollywood for Oscar weekend....
docs.lead_paragraph: Fox Searchlight made the decision to bring the kids of "Slumdog Millionaire" to Hollywood for Oscar weekend. And the kids spread fun and hijinks wherever they went, serving as a reminder that it is fun to dress up, fun to have people clap when you walk in a room, and that while the luster of the Oscars may be fleeting, it is amazing nonetheless.
docs.abstract: Fox Searchlight made the decision to bring the kids of "Slumdog Millionaire" to Hollywood for Oscar weekend.

docs.snippet: Days after their visit to the Academy Awards, two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” have learned they will be moved from a desolate section of Mumbai to new government housing, BBC News reported. Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Days after their visit to the Academy Awards, two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” have learned they will be moved from a desolate section of Mumbai to new government housing, BBC News reported. Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9 (both above with the film’s director, Danny Boyle), who played young incarnations of the characters Salim and Latika in the Oscar-winning film, will be moved from the Garib Nagar slum in Mumbai to houses allocated by the city’s government. The chairman of the local housing association, Amarjeet Singh Manhas, said, “Since the children have made the nation proud, they must be given free houses,” according to the BBC. The plight of the young actors of “Slumdog Millionaire” had prompted an international outcry; the movie’s producers and Mr. Boyle have said that the children were tutored and paid three times an average Indian adult’s salary while working on the film.

Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9, who played young incarnations of the characters Salim and Latika in the Oscar-winning film, will be moved from Mumbai’s Garib Nagar slum to houses allocated by the city’s government. The chairman of the local housing association, Amarjeet Singh Manhas, said, “Since the children have made the nation proud, they must be given free houses,” according to the BBC. The plight of the young actors of “Slumdog Millionaire” had prompted an international outcry; the movie’s producers and its director, Danny Boyle, have said that the children were tutored and paid three times an average Indian adult’s salary while working on the film.
docs.abstract: Days after their visit to the Academy Awards, two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” have learned that they will be moved from a desolate section of Mumbai to new government housing.

headline.main: Slumdogs No More: Film’s Young Stars Get New Homes

docs.snippet: The Bagger is always amazed when people (especially print journalists) take a baseball bat to bloggers. For one thing, it's akin to using a Louisville slugger on a cloud of gnats - doesn't work - and for another, how big of a cultural menace do we...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger is always amazed when people (especially print journalists) whinge about the menace of bloggers. For one thing, it's akin to using a Louisville slugger on a cloud of gnats - doesn't work - and for another, how big of a cultural menace do we actually represent? Don't want to know about what backstage at the Oscars looks like? Then don't go there.
docs.abstract: The Bagger is always amazed when people (especially print journalists) take a baseball bat to bloggers. For one thing, it's akin to using a Louisville slugger on a cloud of gnats - doesn't work - and for another, how big of a cultural menace do we actually represent?

headline.main: The Bagger Over America: Hating on the Dislikers

docs.snippet: Can the climate debate be fact-based?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Many climate scientists, bloggers and readers have weighed in this morning online and in my in-box to complain about my short print story assessing the risk of overstatement or inaccuracy facing everyone pressing an argument about climate science and policy. (I'll include some examples in the comment thread this morning.)
docs.abstract: Can the climate debate be fact-based?

docs.snippet: Up in the Hollywood hills, the Bagger was meeting with a producer who has a well-deserved reputation for decency and effectiveness in a business not known for either....
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Vanity Fair party Sunday night, the Bagger bumped into a guy he knows who is involved in all manner of entertainment businesses. The Bagger noted how the man, someone with access to power in all of its manifestations, seemed to be prospering and was looking well for a middle-aged guy; perhaps he had even lost some weight. "What have you been dining on?" the Bagger asked.
docs.abstract: Up in the Hollywood hills, the Bagger was meeting with a producer who has a well-deserved reputation for decency and effectiveness in a business not known for either.

headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: Scenes from a Dirty Little Town
